EnglishExample.exItem: Representative examples of English embedded Yes/No questions include:
I wonder whether she will come.
I will know if she goes.
Sue wonders whether the boy could have hit the ball.

form.prompt: Key similar examples of embedded Yes/No questions in your language here:
form.instruction: Only certain verbs can take a question complement. In the lexicon, mark the verbs from your examples and any others that come to mind with the features sentential embedded_question if they can only take an embedded question complement (like 'wonder'), but use the features sentential embedded_question_allowed if they can take an embedded question as well as a non-question complement (like 'know').

radioGroup.prompt: For embedded clause Yes/No questions, does your language have one or more Yes/No question marker particles, words or complementizers?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, like whether and if in English

radioGroup.prompt: Is it written as a separate word?
radioGroup.radio: No, it is a clitic which attaches to another word

radioGroup.prompt: Is the clitic a proclitic or an enclitic?
Where does the clitic attach to the embedded Yes/No question?
Where does the Yes/No question marker occur with respect to the rest of the embedded question?
radioGroup.radio: Either side, but not on both sides at the same time
On either side, or on both sides at the same time
Before it, or on both sides at the same time
After it, or on both sides at the same time
Only on both sides at the same time

radioGroup.prompt: Can all the Yes/No question markers appear on either side of the embedded question?
radioGroup.radio: No, there are separate sets for each side
No, but an auxiliary is fronted

radioGroup.prompt: Where does the auxiliary occur with respect to the rest of the question?

radioGroup.radio: No, there is no marker or word order change in embedded clause Yes/No questions, just a difference in intonation or tone or other non-syntactic marking

form.instruction: In the lexicon, add the feature YNQ to these clitics. If a different marker is used in main clause questions, add the feature -root to this entry. If this same marker is used in main clause questions, do not add any root feature.

In the lexicon, add the feature YNQ_prefix to these clitics. If a different marker is used in main clause questions, add the feature +root to this entry. If this same marker is used in main clause questions, do not add any root feature.

In the lexicon, add the feature YNQ_suffix to these clitics. If a different marker is used in main clause questions, add the feature +root to this entry. If this same marker is used in main clause questions, do not add any root feature.

In the lexicon, add the feature YNQ_prefix to the proclitics and add YNQ_suffix to the enclitics. If a different marker is used in main clause questions, add the feature +root to this entry. If this same marker is used in main clause questions, do not add any root feature.

In the lexicon, if this word does not already have the category C, add the feature makeC to the feature line to change the category for the syntax. In either case, add the feature question. If a different marker is used in main clause questions, add the feature +root to this entry. If this same marker is used in main clause questions, do not add any root feature.

In the lexicon, mark those markers which can only occur initially with the feature CP-initial and those which can only occur finally with the feature CP-final. Do not enter either feature on any markers which can occur on either side.
